comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It looks like someone important is arriving or departing from Man o' war wharf.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
The "beautiful boat / ketch" (see note) is HMS Undine - see  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363488946/] . 

This could be a celebration of Queen Victoria's Jubilee in 1887.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: beachcomberaustralia - good point about the 1887 celebrations.  A naval regatta would have been just the thing.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Lifeasdaddy, I was prompted by your post on the other HMS Undine photo which refers to an AWM photo identifying the 1887 Jubilee.

It could also be a celebration for the Centenary in 1888.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I know a bloke who knows a fair bit about Colonial Naval history. I'll see what he can find out. I have tried running combinations of ships' names from the AWM photo through the historic Australian Newspapers search function at the National Library of Australia to no avail thus far. That search does not include the Sydney Morning Herald due to various rights issues - which does reduce effectiveness for this purpose. newspapers.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/home

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Tentative ship identifications based on this AWM 1887 Queen Victoria Jubilee photo - cas.awm.gov.au/item/302177 . Taken from the other direction, and the wind has changed!

comment.author: 56512128@N06
comment._content: TYPES OF FOREIGN MEN-OF-WAR; . (See illustrations on page 390.) ' . It is many years. since Port Jackson- especially that portion of it known as Farm Cove-has presented such an attractive appearance' as during-the last couple of months. In the first place there' were the Nelson one of the first-class cruising ironclads of the British Navy ; H.M.S. Rapid, a powerful and handy composite vessel specially adapted for the colonies or foreign stations ; the serviceable oomposite vessels Diamond and Opal ; the gun boats Swinger and Raven; and the two schooner-yachts, Harrier and Undine. TYPES OF FOREIGN MEN-OF-WAR. (1887, August 20).Australian Town and Country Journal (NSW : 1870 - 1907), p. 26. Retrieved from nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71088385
